Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is funded as part of the United States-Israel Collaboration in Computer Science (USICCS) program. Through this program, NSF and the United States - Israel Binational Science Foundation (BSF) jointly support collaborations among US-based researchers and Israel-based researchers.

This project will examine and extend computational techniques that allow computers to out-perform humans on certain classes of difficult problems, some of which have practical applications across many areas of science and engineering. The techniques to be studied, which are modeled on biological processes of evolution, have already been shown to produce human-competitive performance in areas ranging from pure mathematics to quantum system design, and from game-playing systems to software engineering and debugging. In this project the co-PIs will collaborate to characterize the application areas in which these human-competitive successes have been achieved, along with the specific techniques that were used in each case. The project will use these characterizations to guide improvements to the techniques and applications to new problems.

The initial data for the study will be taken from the winners of the of the Human Competitive Results Competition that has been held annually since 2004 at the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference. Areas of anticipated application work include software engineering, for example for automatic program synthesis and repair, where early successes and the scale of the potential applications indicate substantial promise. The long-term potential of work in this area is for computers to automatically generate useful software, for many applications of scientific or social significance, that would be prohibitively difficult or expensive for human programmers to produce. The project will be conducted with undergraduates and graduate students and will also thereby help to train future innovators in computer science.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goals of this project were to examine and extend computational techniques that allow computers to out-perform humans on certain classes of difficult problems, some of which have practical applications across many areas of science and engineering. The techniques studied, which are modeled on biological processes of evolution, had already been shown to produce human-competitive performance in areas ranging from pure mathematics to quantum algorithm design, and from game-playing systems to software engineering and debugging. In this project the participants collaborated to characterize the application areas in which these human-competitive successes had been achieved, along with the specific techniques that were used in each case. The project then used these characterizations to guide improvements to the techniques and applications to new problems.

The participants produced and published an analysis of the winners of the Human Competitive Results Competition that has been held annually since 2004 at the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference, characterizing both the specific computational techniques and the application areas that appear to be most promising for the production of human-competitive results. Among the results of this analysis are the observations that the technique known as "genetic programming" has been the most successful for producing human-competitive results so far, that design problems appear to be particularly good candidates for the production of human-competitive results, and that most of human-competitive results stem from close collaboration between evolutionary computation practitioners and application-area experts. 

Work on this project also advanced the state of the art in evolutionary computation by developing and refining new methods by which promising candidate solutions can be expressed and selected for further exploration, new methods for exploration in the local "neighborhood" of those candidate solutions, and new ways to analyze and visualize the results of evolutionary search. The developed methods were applied to the automation of programming tasks normally undertaken by human programmers, to the modeling of complex dynamic systems such as wind turbines, and to biomedical classification. 

Future impacts of the results of this project may stem from the power of the systems that it advanced to produce solutions to significant problems in several areas of science and engineering. Steps were taken to make the ideas and tools developed in this project available to wider communities, such as data scientists who have no prior experience with evolutionary computation. The project was conducted with undergraduates and graduate students, and therefore also helped to train future innovators in computer science.


Last Modified: 12/20/2017
Modified by: Lee Spector

The techniques studied, which are modeled on biological processes of evolution, had already been shown to produce human-competitive performance in areas ranging from pure mathematics to quantum algorithm design, and from game-playing systems to software engineering and debugging. In this project the participants collaborated to characterize the application areas in which these human-competitive successes had been achieved, along with the specific techniques that were used in each case. The project then used these characterizations to guide improvements to the techniques and applications to new problems. The participants produced and published an analysis of the winners of the Human Competitive Results Competition that has been held annually since 2004 at the Genetic and Evolutionary Computation Conference, characterizing both the specific computational techniques and the application areas that appear to be most promising for the production of human-competitive results. Among the results of this analysis are the observations that the technique known as "genetic programming" has been the most successful for producing human-competitive results so far, that design problems appear to be particularly good candidates for the production of human-competitive results, and that most of human-competitive results stem from close collaboration between evolutionary computation practitioners and application-area experts. Future impacts of the results of this project may stem from the power of the systems that it advanced to produce solutions to significant problems in several areas of science and engineering. Steps were taken to make the ideas and tools developed in this project available to wider communities, such as data scientists who have no prior experience with evolutionary computation. The project was conducted with undergraduates and graduate students, and therefore also helped to train future innovators in computer science. Last Modified: 12/20/2017 Submitted by: Lee Spector
